keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a major heist in October 2025, with nine high-value historical artifacts stolen from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.
The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces of jewelry from Empress Eugénie.
One of the most valuable items, the reliquary brooch, features the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, originally given to Louis XIV by Cardinal Mazarin in 1661.
The emerald necklace and earrings, valued at 3.7 million euros, were acquired by the Louvre in 2004 from Van Cleef & Arpels after being passed through generations of Marie-Louise’s descendants.
The reliquary brooch was purchased by the Louvre in 2008 for 6.72 million euros, reflecting its status as a high-value cultural artifact.
A sapphire diadem with 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds was once owned by queens including Marie-Amélie and Isabelle d’Orléans and was acquired by the Louvre in 1985.
The heist is described as a 'national disaster' by art recovery expert Arthur Brand, due to the loss of France's crown jewels and national heritage.
One item, Empress Eugénie's crown, was recovered outside the museum, though it was damaged during the theft.
Experts believe the thieves will dismantle and melt down the stolen gold and silver to sell the precious stones, indicating a likely attempt to profit from the loss.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a shocking heist on October 20, 2025, nine precious historical artifacts were stolen from the Louvre Museum’s Apollo Gallery in Paris in just seven minutes. Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces of jewelry belonging to Empress Eugénie. The items, which include a reliquary brooch with the historic Mazarin diamonds and a diamond bow brooch crafted from a 19th-century belt, were valued at millions of euros. Experts describe the heist as a 'national disaster' due to the loss of France’s crown jewels and national heritage. One of the items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered outside the museum but was damaged during the theft. Art recovery expert Arthur Brand warns that the thieves will likely dismantle and melt the gold and silver to sell the gemstones, indicating a potential effort to profit from the theft. The cultural and historical significance of these items—crafted by renowned jewelers and passed through generations of royal families—makes the theft a profound blow to French national identity and cultural preservation.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
